segment.source: Microsoft BitLocker Administration and Monitoring (MBAM) 2.5 provides a simplified administrative interface for BitLocker Drive Encryption.
segment.target: Microsoft BitLocker Administration and Monitoring (MBAM) 2.5 provides a simplified administrative interface for BitLocker Drive Encryption.

segment.source: BitLocker offers enhanced protection against data theft or data exposure for computers that are lost or stolen.
segment.target: BitLocker offers enhanced protection against data theft or data exposure for computers that are lost or stolen.

segment.source: BitLocker encrypts all data that is stored on the Windows operating system volumes and drives and configured data drives.
segment.target: BitLocker encrypts all data that is stored on the Windows operating system volumes and drives and configured data drives.

segment.source: Overview of MBAM
segment.target: Overview of MBAM

segment.source: MBAM 2.5 has the following features:
segment.target: MBAM 2.5 has the following features:

segment.source: Enables administrators to automate the process of encrypting volumes on client computers across the enterprise.
segment.target: Enables administrators to automate the process of encrypting volumes on client computers across the enterprise.

segment.source: Enables security officers to quickly determine the compliance state of individual computers or even of the enterprise itself.
segment.target: Enables security officers to quickly determine the compliance state of individual computers or even of the enterprise itself.

segment.source: Provides centralized reporting and hardware management with Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager.
segment.target: Provides centralized reporting and hardware management with Microsoft System Center Configuration Manager.

segment.source: Reduces the workload on the Help Desk to assist end users with BitLocker PIN and recovery key requests.
segment.target: Reduces the workload on the Help Desk to assist end users with BitLocker PIN and recovery key requests.

segment.source: Enables end users to recover encrypted devices independently by using the Self-Service Portal.
segment.target: Enables end users to recover encrypted devices independently by using the Self-Service Portal.

segment.source: Enables security officers to easily audit access to recover key information.
segment.target: Enables security officers to easily audit access to recover key information.

segment.source: Empowers Windows Enterprise users to continue working anywhere with the assurance that their corporate data is protected.
segment.target: Empowers Windows Enterprise users to continue working anywhere with the assurance that their corporate data is protected.

segment.source: MBAM enforces the BitLocker encryption policy options that you set for your enterprise, monitors the compliance of client computers with those policies, and reports on the encryption status of the enterprise’s and individual’s computers.
segment.target: MBAM enforces the BitLocker encryption policy options that you set for your enterprise, monitors the compliance of client computers with those policies, and reports on the encryption status of the enterprise’s and individual’s computers.

segment.source: In addition, MBAM lets you access the recovery key information when users forget their PIN or password, or when their BIOS or boot records change.
segment.target: In addition, MBAM lets you access the recovery key information when users forget their PIN or password, or when their BIOS or boot records change.

segment.source: Ability to enforce encryption policies on operating system and fixed data drives
segment.target: Ability to enforce encryption policies on operating system and fixed data drives

segment.source: MBAM 2.5 enables you to enforce encryption policies on operating system and fixed data drives for computers in your organization and limit the number of days that end users can request a postponement of the requirement to comply with MBAM encryption policies.
segment.target: MBAM 2.5 enables you to enforce encryption policies on operating system and fixed data drives for computers in your organization and limit the number of days that end users can request a postponement of the requirement to comply with MBAM encryption policies.

segment.source: To enable you to configure encryption policy enforcement, a new Group Policy setting, called Encryption Policy Enforcement Settings, has been added for operating system drives and fixed data drives.
segment.target: To enable you to configure encryption policy enforcement, a new Group Policy setting, called Encryption Policy Enforcement Settings, has been added for operating system drives and fixed data drives.

segment.source: Encryption Policy Enforcement Settings (Operating System Drive)
segment.target: Encryption Policy Enforcement Settings (Operating System Drive)

segment.source: For this setting, use the option Configure the number of noncompliance grace period days for operating system drives to configure a grace period.
segment.target: For this setting, use the option Configure the number of noncompliance grace period days for operating system drives to configure a grace period.

segment.source: The grace period specifies the number of days that end users can postpone compliance with MBAM policies for their operating system drive after the drive is first detected as noncompliant.
segment.target: The grace period specifies the number of days that end users can postpone compliance with MBAM policies for their operating system drive after the drive is first detected as noncompliant.

segment.source: After the configured grace period expires, users cannot postpone the required action or request an exemption from it.
segment.target: After the configured grace period expires, users cannot postpone the required action or request an exemption from it.

segment.source: If user interaction is required (for example, if you are using the Trusted Platform Module (TPM) + PIN or using a password protector), a dialog box appears, and users cannot close it until they provide the required information.
segment.target: If user interaction is required (for example, if you are using the Trusted Platform Module (TPM) + PIN or using a password protector), a dialog box appears, and users cannot close it until they provide the required information.

segment.source: If the protector is TPM only, encryption begins immediately in the background without user input.
segment.target: If the protector is TPM only, encryption begins immediately in the background without user input.

segment.source: Users cannot request exemptions through the BitLocker encryption wizard.
segment.target: Users cannot request exemptions through the BitLocker encryption wizard.

segment.source: Instead, they must contact their Help Desk or use whatever process their organization uses for exemption requests.
segment.target: Instead, they must contact their Help Desk or use whatever process their organization uses for exemption requests.

segment.target: Encryption Policy Enforcement Settings (Fixed Data Drives)

segment.source: For this setting, use the option Configure the number of noncompliance grace period days for fixed drives to configure a grace period.
segment.target: For this setting, use the option Configure the number of noncompliance grace period days for fixed drives to configure a grace period.

segment.source: The grace period specifies the number of days that end users can postpone compliance with MBAM policies for their fixed drive after the drive is first detected as noncompliant.
segment.target: The grace period specifies the number of days that end users can postpone compliance with MBAM policies for their fixed drive after the drive is first detected as noncompliant.

segment.source: The grace period begins when the fixed drive is determined to be noncompliant.
segment.target: The grace period begins when the fixed drive is determined to be noncompliant.

segment.source: Support for FIPS-compliant recovery keys
segment.target: Support for FIPS-compliant recovery keys

segment.source: MBAM 2.5 supports Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS)-compliant BitLocker recovery keys on devices that are running the Windows 8.1 operating system.
segment.target: MBAM 2.5 supports Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS)-compliant BitLocker recovery keys on devices that are running the Windows 8.1 operating system.

segment.source: The recovery key was not FIPS compliant in earlier versions of Windows.
segment.target: The recovery key was not FIPS compliant in earlier versions of Windows.

segment.source: This enhancement improves the drive recovery process in organizations that require FIPS compliance because it enables end users to use the Self-Service Portal or Administration and Monitoring Website (Help Desk) to recover their drives if they forget their PIN or password or get locked out of their computers.
segment.target: This enhancement improves the drive recovery process in organizations that require FIPS compliance because it enables end users to use the Self-Service Portal or Administration and Monitoring Website (Help Desk) to recover their drives if they forget their PIN or password or get locked out of their computers.

segment.source: The new FIPS compliance feature does not extend to password protectors.
segment.target: The new FIPS compliance feature does not extend to password protectors.

segment.source: To enable FIPS compliance in your organization, you must configure the Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) Group Policy settings.
segment.target: To enable FIPS compliance in your organization, you must configure the Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) Group Policy settings.

segment.source: For configuration instructions, see BitLocker Group Policy Settings.
segment.target: For configuration instructions, see BitLocker Group Policy Settings.

segment.source: For client computers that are running the Windows 8 or Windows 7 operating systems without the installed BitLocker hotfix, IT administrators will continue to use the Data Recovery Agents (DRA) protector in FIPS-compliant environments.
segment.target: For client computers that are running the Windows 8 or Windows 7 operating systems without the installed BitLocker hotfix, IT administrators will continue to use the Data Recovery Agents (DRA) protector in FIPS-compliant environments.

segment.source: For information about DRA, see Using Data Recovery Agents with BitLocker.
segment.target: For information about DRA, see Using Data Recovery Agents with BitLocker.

segment.source: See Hotfix Package 2 for BitLocker Administration and Monitoring 2.5 to download and install the BitLocker hotfix for Windows 7 and Windows 8 computers.
segment.target: See Hotfix Package 2 for BitLocker Administration and Monitoring 2.5 to download and install the BitLocker hotfix for Windows 7 and Windows 8 computers.

segment.target: In previous versions of MBAM, roles were managed by using local groups.

segment.source: Allow enhanced PINs for startup Group Policy setting
segment.target: Allow enhanced PINs for startup Group Policy setting

segment.source: The Group Policy setting, Allow enhanced PINs for startup, enables you to configure whether enhanced startup PINs are used with BitLocker.
segment.target: The Group Policy setting, Allow enhanced PINs for startup, enables you to configure whether enhanced startup PINs are used with BitLocker.

segment.source: Enhanced startup PINs permit users to enter any keys on a full keyboard, including uppercase and lowercase letters, symbols, numbers, and spaces.
segment.target: Enhanced startup PINs permit users to enter any keys on a full keyboard, including uppercase and lowercase letters, symbols, numbers, and spaces.

segment.source: If you enable this policy setting, all new BitLocker startup PINs that are set will be enhanced PINs.
segment.target: If you enable this policy setting, all new BitLocker startup PINs that are set will be enhanced PINs.

segment.source: If you disable or do not configure this policy setting, enhanced PINs cannot be used.
segment.target: If you disable or do not configure this policy setting, enhanced PINs cannot be used.

segment.source: Not all computers support the entry of enhanced PINs in the Pre-Boot Execution Environment (PXE).
segment.target: Not all computers support the entry of enhanced PINs in the Pre-Boot Execution Environment (PXE).

segment.source: Before you enable this Group Policy setting for your organization, run a system check during the BitLocker setup process to ensure that the computer’s BIOS supports the use of the full keyboard in PXE.
segment.target: Before you enable this Group Policy setting for your organization, run a system check during the BitLocker setup process to ensure that the computer’s BIOS supports the use of the full keyboard in PXE.

segment.source: For more information, see Planning for MBAM 2.5 Group Policy Requirements.
segment.target: For more information, see Planning for MBAM 2.5 Group Policy Requirements.

segment.source: Require ASCII-only PINs check box
segment.target: Require ASCII-only PINs check box

segment.source: The Allow enhanced PINs for startup Group Policy setting also contains a Require ASCII-only PINs check box.
segment.target: The Allow enhanced PINs for startup Group Policy setting also contains a Require ASCII-only PINs check box.

segment.source: If the computers in your organization do not support the use of the full keyboard in PXE, you can enable the Allow enhanced PINs for startup Group Policy setting, and then select the Require ASCII-only PINs check box to require that enhanced PINs use only printable ASCII characters.
segment.target: If the computers in your organization do not support the use of the full keyboard in PXE, you can enable the Allow enhanced PINs for startup Group Policy setting, and then select the Require ASCII-only PINs check box to require that enhanced PINs use only printable ASCII characters.

segment.source: Enforced use of nonsequential and nonrepeating characters
segment.target: Enforced use of nonsequential and nonrepeating characters

segment.source: MBAM 2.5 prevents end users from creating PINs that consist of repeating numbers (such as 1111) or sequential numbers (such as 1234).
segment.target: MBAM 2.5 prevents end users from creating PINs that consist of repeating numbers (such as 1111) or sequential numbers (such as 1234).

segment.source: If end users try to enter a password that contains three or more repeating or sequential numbers, the Bitlocker Drive Encryption wizard displays an error message and prevents users from entering a PIN with the prohibited characters.
segment.target: If end users try to enter a password that contains three or more repeating or sequential numbers, the Bitlocker Drive Encryption wizard displays an error message and prevents users from entering a PIN with the prohibited characters.

segment.source: Support for multi-forest support deployments
segment.target: Support for multi-forest support deployments

segment.source: MBAM 2.5 supports the following types of multi-forest deployments:
segment.target: MBAM 2.5 supports the following types of multi-forest deployments:

segment.source: Single forest with single domain
segment.target: Single forest with single domain

segment.source: Single forest with a single tree and multiple domains
segment.target: Single forest with a single tree and multiple domains

segment.source: Single forest with multiple trees and disjoint namespaces
segment.target: Single forest with multiple trees and disjoint namespaces

segment.source: Multiple forests in a central forest topology
segment.target: Multiple forests in a central forest topology

segment.source: Multiple forests in a resource forest topology
segment.target: Multiple forests in a resource forest topology

segment.source: There is no support for forest migration (going from single to multiple, multiple to single, resource to across the forest, etc.), or upgrade or downgrade.
segment.target: There is no support for forest migration (going from single to multiple, multiple to single, resource to across the forest, etc.), or upgrade or downgrade.

segment.source: The prerequisites for deploying MBAM in multi-forest deployments are:
segment.target: The prerequisites for deploying MBAM in multi-forest deployments are:

segment.source: Forest must be running on supported versions of Windows Server.
segment.target: Forest must be running on supported versions of Windows Server.

segment.source: A two-way or one-way trust is required.
segment.target: A two-way or one-way trust is required.

segment.source: One-way trusts require that the server’s domain trusts the client’s domain.
segment.target: One-way trusts require that the server’s domain trusts the client’s domain.

segment.source: In other words, the server’s domain is pointed at the client’s domain.
segment.target: In other words, the server’s domain is pointed at the client’s domain.

segment.source: MBAM Client support for Encrypted Hard Drives
segment.target: MBAM Client support for Encrypted Hard Drives

segment.source: MBAM supports BitLocker on Encrypted Hard Drives that meet TCG specification requirements for Opal as well as IEEE 1667 standards.
segment.target: MBAM supports BitLocker on Encrypted Hard Drives that meet TCG specification requirements for Opal as well as IEEE 1667 standards.

segment.source: When BitLocker is enabled on these devices, it will generate keys and perform management functions on the encrypted drive.
segment.target: When BitLocker is enabled on these devices, it will generate keys and perform management functions on the encrypted drive.

segment.source: See Encrypted Hard Drive for more information.
segment.target: See Encrypted Hard Drive for more information.
